title: 113_hr2072
content: The "Demanding Accountability for Veterans Act of 2014" requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to be accountable to the Inspector General of the Department of Veterans Affairs. The budgetary effects of the Act must comply with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. The "Demanding Accountability for Veterans Act of 2014" mandates the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to be accountable to the Inspector General by submitting a list of responsible managers if significant progress is not made in response to a covered report. The "Demanding Accountability for Veterans Act of 2014" requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to submit a list of responsible managers to the Inspector General for addressing covered issues. The Secretary must notify managers promptly, direct them to resolve issues, provide counseling, and ensure performance reviews include an evaluation of their actions in response to the issues. The Inspector General cannot disclose the names of responsible managers publicly. The "Demanding Accountability for Veterans Act of 2014" requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to submit responsible managers to the Inspector General for addressing covered issues. The Secretary cannot pay bonuses if issues remain unresolved. The Inspector General has additional authority under this section. Definitions include "covered issue" and "covered report." The "Demanding Accountability for Veterans Act of 2014" mandates the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to identify responsible managers for addressing issues related to public health or safety within the Department. The term "responsible manager" is defined as an employee in a management position accountable for a covered report. The "Demanding Accountability for Veterans Act of 2014" mandates the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to identify responsible managers for addressing issues related to public health or safety within the Department. Additionally, the Secretary has accountability to the Inspector General. The Act also grants the Secretary contract authority for transferring veterans to non-department medical foster homes. During a three-year period starting on October 1, 2014, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs can transfer veterans needing nursing home care to medical foster homes meeting Department standards. The veterans must agree to receive home health services as part of the transfer. Effective October 1, 2014, a home is defined as a non-institutional, long-term supportive care option for veterans unable to live independently. SEC. 5. CONDITIONS ON PER DIEM PAYMENTS BY THE SECRETARY OF VETERANS AFFAIRS FOR HOUSING OR SERVICES TO HOMELESS VETERANS. The amendment requires grant recipients to submit an annual certification of compliance with relevant codes for facilities providing housing or services to homeless veterans using grant funds. The amendment mandates grant recipients to certify compliance with local codes, licensing, fire, and safety requirements for facilities offering housing or services to homeless veterans using grant funds. The Secretary will determine requirements for facilities in jurisdictions without relevant codes. Effective for applications submitted after the enactment date. The amendment requires grant recipients to certify the safety and accessibility of facilities used for programs under sections 2011 and 2012 of title 38. Recipients of per diem payments must submit the certification as well. The amendment mandates grant recipients to certify the safety and accessibility of facilities used for programs under sections 2011 and 2012 of title 38. Recipients must submit the certification within two years of the enactment of the Act. Failure to do so will result in the suspension of additional per diem payments until the certification is submitted. SEC. 6. EXTENSION OF LOAN GUARANTY FEE FOR CERTAIN SUBSEQUENT LOANS. Extension of loan guaranty fee for certain subsequent loans under Section 3729(b)(2) of title 38, United States Code is amended to change the effective date from October 1, 2017, to October 1, 2018. SEC. 7. Extension of authority for the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to obtain information from the Secretary of the Treasury or the Commissioner of Social Security is extended from September 30, 2016, to May 31, 2017.
